content: The "Child Citizenship Act of 2000" allows for automatic acquisition of citizenship for certain children born outside the United States and residing permanently in the country. This is an amendment to Section 320 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Child Citizenship Act of 2000 grants automatic citizenship to children born outside the US if at least one parent is a US citizen, the child is under 18, and residing in the US under the legal custody of the citizen parent. Adoption by a US citizen parent also qualifies under specific conditions. Children born outside the US and residing permanently in the US can acquire citizenship automatically under specific conditions. Children born outside the US can acquire citizenship under specific conditions outlined in Section 322 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. A parent who is a US citizen can apply for naturalization for a child born outside the US under Section 322 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The parent must prove that at least one parent is a US citizen and meet specific physical presence requirements in the US. A child born outside the US to a US citizen parent can become a citizen through naturalization under Section 322 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The child must have lived in the US for at least five years, with two years after turning fourteen, be under eighteen, reside outside the US in the custody of the citizen parent, and be temporarily present in the US with lawful status. Upon approval of the application and taking the oath of allegiance, the child will receive a certificate of citizenship from the Attorney General. A child adopted by a US citizen parent can acquire citizenship under Section 322 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The child must meet the requirements for adopted children and will receive a certificate of citizenship from the Attorney General.
